title.children: Coast Guard says debris field points to 'catastrophic' loss of pressure in missing submersible

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Liability waivers signed by passengers on the submersible lost at sea during a dive to the Titanic wreck may not shield OceanGate from potential lawsuits by the victims' families, legal experts said. The passengers, who paid as much as $US250,000 ($360,000) each for the journey to 3,810 meters below the surface, are believed to have signed liability waivers. A CBS reporter who made the trip with OceanGate Expeditions in July 2022 reported that the waiver he signed mentioned the possibility of death three times on the first page alone. Reuters could not independently confirm the terms of OceanGate's waivers. OceanGate did not immediately respond to requests for comment. Waivers are not always ironclad, and it is not uncommon for judges to reject them if there is evidence of gross negligence or hazards that were not fully disclosed. "If there were aspects of the design or construction of this vessel that were kept from the passengers or it was knowingly operated despite information that it was not suitable for this dive, that would absolutely go against the validity of the waiver," said personal injury attorney and maritime law expert Matthew Shaffer. OceanGate could argue it was not grossly negligent and that the waivers apply because they fully described the dangers inherent in plumbing the deepest reaches of the ocean in a submersible the size of a minivan. The degree of any potential negligence and how that might impact the applicability of the waivers will depend on the causes of the disaster, which are still under investigation. "There are so many different examples of what families might still have claims for despite the waivers, but until we know the cause we can't determine whether the waivers apply," said personal injury lawyer Joseph Low. The families could not be reached on Thursday. It is possible none of them will sue. Reporting by Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Victims' families could still sue despite liability waivers, legal experts say

children.content: Liability waivers signed by passengers on the submersible lost at sea during a dive to the Titanic wreck may not shield OceanGate from potential lawsuits by the victims' families, legal experts said.
The passengers, who paid as much as $US250,000 ($360,000) each for the journey to 3,810 meters below the surface, are believed to have signed liability waivers.
A CBS reporter who made the trip with OceanGate Expeditions in July 2022 reported that the waiver he signed
mentioned the possibility of death three times on the first page alone.
(Supplied: OceanGate Expeditions)
Reuters could not independently confirm the terms of OceanGate's waivers. OceanGate did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
Waivers are not always ironclad, and it is
not uncommon for judges to reject them if there is evidence of gross negligence
or hazards that were not fully disclosed.

"If there were aspects of the design or construction of this vessel that were kept from the passengers or it was knowingly operated despite information that it was not suitable for this dive, that would absolutely go against the validity of the waiver," said personal injury attorney and maritime law expert
Matthew Shaffer.
OceanGate could argue it was not grossly negligent and that the waivers apply because they
fully described the dangers
inherent in plumbing the deepest reaches of the ocean in a submersible the size of a minivan.
The degree of any potential negligence and how that might impact the applicability of the waivers
will depend on the causes of the disaster, which are still under investigation.

"There are so many different examples of what families might still have claims for despite the waivers, but until we know the cause we can't determine whether the waivers apply," said personal injury lawyer
Joseph Low.
The families could not be reached on Thursday. It is possible none of them will sue.
Reporting by Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hamish Harding, a British billionaire who served as chairman for aircraft-brokering company Action Aviation, was one of the mission specialists on the submersible and had paid to go on the expedition. The company has released a short statement, writing: "Action Aviation are united in grief with the other families who have also lost their loved ones of the Titan submersible."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'United in grief': Hamish Harding's company responds

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Father and son Shahzada and Suleman Dawood were members of one of Pakistan's most prominent families. "It is with profound grief that we announce the passing of Shahzada and Suleman Dawood who were aboard OceanGate's Titan submersible."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Fears are mounting that the British economy is heading for recession the Bank of England increased interest rates by an unexpected half-a-percentage point to a 15-year high. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and his ministers are feeling the pressure after back to back rate rises - this was the 13th in a row, and will make it harder for homeowners in Britain already hit by sharp hikes in the cost of food and fuel. The Bank of England said its nine-member Monetary Policy Committee cautioned that wages growth would likely slow from here. It said inflation should ease later in the year, and higher interest rates were yet to really bite the many Britons on fixed-rate mortgages. "There has been significant upside news in recent data that indicates more persistence in the inflation process, against the background of a tight labour market and continued resilience in demand," the MPC said in a statement after the meeting. It added that "if there were to be evidence of more persistent pressures, then further tightening in monetary policy would be required."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is Britain heading towards a recession?

props.alt: Rishi Sunak in a blue suit

children.content: UK PM Rishi Sunak is facing pressure after 13 rate rises
(Reuters: John Sibley)
Fears are mounting that the British economy is heading for recession the Bank of England increased interest rates by an unexpected half-a-percentage point to a 15-year high.

Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and his ministers are feeling the pressure after back to back rate rises - this was the 13th in a row, and will make it harder for homeowners in Britain already hit by sharp hikes in the cost of food and fuel.
The Bank of England said its nine-member Monetary Policy Committee cautioned that wages growth would likely slow from here.
It said inflation should ease later in the year, and higher interest rates were yet to really bite the many Britons on fixed-rate mortgages.

"There has been significant upside news in recent data that indicates more persistence in the inflation process, against the background of a tight labour market and continued resilience in demand," the MPC said in a statement after the meeting.
It added that "if there were to be evidence of more persistent pressures, then further tightening in monetary policy would be required."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A plan to make multinationals publicly report their tax data is being fought by Australia's biggest companies that have warned the Albanese government that new rules will significantly increase the cost of doing business. Treasury is consulting about making country-by-country tax reporting rules for multinational firms publicly available. Companies already report this information to tax authorities but have long warned against making it public. The change would require them to publicly report tax information on a country-by-country basis worldwide, as well as data that shows if authorities are targeting aggressive transfer pricing tactics used by multinationals. Business leaders warn the rules will mean Australia imposes some of the toughest disclosure rules in the world, over and above requirements already in place in the European Union. But Jason Ward, principal analyst at the Center for International Corporate Tax Accountability and Research, said disclosures would be an "incredible data source" for tax activists, shareholders and academics. All companies with global revenues over $1 billion that operate in Australia would need to list the tangible and intangible assets they hold in each jurisdiction with book values, according to the draft rules, scheduled to apply for income years beginning from July 1. But the proposed changes have now been delayed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Business fights multinational tax reporting rules

children.content: A plan to make multinationals publicly report their tax data is being fought by Australia's biggest companies that have warned the Albanese government that new rules will significantly increase the cost of doing business.
Buiness argues the changes will be a cost impost
(Giulio Saggin, file photo: ABC News)
Treasury is consulting about making country-by-country tax reporting rules for multinational firms publicly available.
Companies already report this information to tax authorities but have long warned against making it public.

The change would require them to publicly report tax information on a country-by-country basis worldwide, as well as data that shows if authorities are targeting aggressive transfer pricing tactics used by multinationals.
Business leaders warn the rules will mean Australia imposes some of the toughest disclosure rules in the world, over and above requirements already in place in the European Union.

But Jason Ward, principal analyst at the Center for International Corporate Tax Accountability and Research, said disclosures would be an "incredible data source" for tax activists, shareholders and academics.

All companies with global revenues over $1 billion that operate in Australia would need to list the tangible and intangible assets they hold in each jurisdiction with book values, according to the draft rules, scheduled to apply for income years beginning from July 1.
But the proposed changes have now been delayed.
